text.s: William Kamkwamba: Thanks.

p.s: CA: So, we've got a picture, I think?
CA: Five years ago you had an idea.

text.s: WK: I wanted to make a windmill.
CA: A windmill?
WK: Yeah.
CA: What, to power -- for lighting and stuff?
WK: Yeah.

p.s: CA: So what did you do?

text.s: WK: After I dropped out of school, I went to library, and I read a book that would -- "Using Energy," and I get information about doing the mill.
And I tried, and I made it.
(Applause) CA: So you copied -- you exactly copied the design in the book.
WK: In fact, a design of the windmill that was in the book, it has got four -- ah -- three blades, and mine has got four blades.
CA: The book had three, yours had four.
WK: Yeah.
CA: And you made it out of what?
WK: I made four blades, just because I want to increase power.
CA: OK.
WK: Yeah.
CA: You tested three, and found that four worked better?
CA: And what did you make the windmill out of?
What materials did you use?

p.s: WK: I use a bicycle frame, and a pulley, and plastic pipe, what then pulls -- CA: Do we have a picture of that?
Can we have the next slide?

text.s: CA: And so, and that windmill, what -- it worked?
WK: When the wind blows, it rotates and generates.
CA: How much electricity?
WK: 12 watts.

p.s: CA: And so, that lit a light for the house?

text.s: WK: Four bulbs and two radios.
CA: Wow.
WK: Yeah.
(Applause) CA: Next slide -- so who's that?
WK: This is my parents, holding the radio.

p.s: CA: So what did they make of -- that you were 14, 15 at the time -- what did they make of this?

text.s: WK: Yeah.
CA: And so what's your -- what are you going to do with this?
WK: Um -- CA: What do you -- I mean -- do you want to build another one?
WK: Yeah, I want to build another one -- to pump water and irrigation for crops.
CA: So this one would have to be bigger?
WK: Yeah.
CA: How big?
WK: I think it will produce more than 20 the watts.
CA: So that would produce irrigation for the entire village?
WK: Yeah.

p.s: And so you're talking to people here at TED to get people who might be able to help in some way to realize this dream?

text.s: WK: Yeah, if they can help me with materials, yeah.
CA: And as you think of your life going forward, you're 19 now, do you picture continuing with this dream of working in energy?

p.s: I'm still thinking to work on energy.
William, it's a real honor to have you at the TED conference.

text.s: Thank you so much for coming.
WK: Thank you.
(Applause)
